statement.p: Find all critical numbers of g that lie in the interval -2 \le x \le 3.

hint.p: Check that each critical number you find satisfies -2 \le x \le 3.

solution.p: Since g'(x) = x^2 - 2, the critical numbers of g are x = \pm \sqrt{2} \approx \pm 1.414, both of which lie in the interval -2 \le x \le 3.

statement.p: From the graph, determine the x-values at which the absolute minimum and absolute maximum of g occur on the interval [-2,3].

hint.p: On the graph, look for the lowest and highest possible values of the function.

answer.p: On [-2,3], g has a global maximum at x = 3 and a global minimum at x = \sqrt{2}.

solution.p: On [-2,3], g has a global maximum at x = 3 and a global minimum at x = \sqrt{2}.

statement.p: How do your answers change if we instead consider the interval -2 \le x \le 2?

hint.p: Ask yourself the same questions as (a)-(c), simply using the new interval.

answer.p: On [-2,2], g has a global maximum at x = -\sqrt{2} and a global minimum at x = \sqrt{2}.

solution.p: On [-2,2], g has a global maximum at x = -\sqrt{2} and a global minimum at x = \sqrt{2}.

answer.p: On [-2,1], g has a global maximum at x = -\sqrt{2} and a global minimum at x = 1.
